Clinical Rationale: Albumin in urine indicates glomerular damage
Waste product; elevated when kidneys fail
Anaemia common in CKD; low Hb is a marker
Kidney concentrating ability decreases in CKD
Diabetes is the leading cause of CKD
Packed cell volume reduced in CKD anaemia
RBC count falls with renal anaemia
Hypertension causes and accelerates CKD
Diabetic nephropathy is a primary CKD cause
RBC casts in urine signal glomerulonephritis
Elevated BP associated with CKD progression
Sodium imbalance in advanced CKD (hyponatraemia)
Urea retention is a hallmark of renal failure
Glucosuria in diabetic nephropathy
Elevated in infection/inflammation; indirect
Poor appetite is a symptom of uraemia
Oedema from fluid retention in CKD
Hyperkalaemia occurs as GFR declines
Pus cells indicate infection / inflammation
Older age is an independent risk factor
Renal anaemia results from EPO deficiency
Pus cell clumps indicate UTI/renal infection
Bacteriuria associated with renal infection
Cardiovascular disease co-morbid with CKD
